metadata.titel_preek: Epiphany and the Baptism of the Lord

locutie.beschrijving: The sermon explores the 'fear of the Lord' through Gideon and Peter, and the 'new thing' of God's grace in the Baptism of Christ and the suffering servant.
locutie.exegetische_kwaliteit: High. Strong focus on the historical context of the Babylonian exile and the literary parallels between OT epiphanies and NT gospel accounts.

illocutie.beschrijving: Primarily asserting theological truths about God's nature, with a late shift toward promising grace and declaring the hearer's status.
voorbeelden: Grace is terrifying.
God is opposed to us.
I bring you good tidings of great joy.

perlocutie.beoogd_effect: To move the hearer from 'holy dread' to the comfort of 'unmerited mercy'.
perlocutie.pneumatologisch_bewustzijn: Implicit in the prayers, but the sermon text itself focuses more on the Christological event than the Spirit's current agency.

voorbeelden: The combination of heavenly grace and earthly fear is one of the most powerful recurrent themes.
Gideon is not in the least a mighty man of valor.
The Epiphany season marks the transition from the manger to the cross.
Notice that, in the Old Testament...
Count yourself blessed.
Listen to these words.
I think this is supposed to be funny.
I remember a fascinating story.
We can understand and even admire the hope.
I will be with you.
The next words that you hear will be: Fear not.
He puts redemption into our blanket.
commissieven.kwaliteit: Strong but often framed as historical narrative rather than immediate address.

voorbeelden: Peace be to you.
Your iniquity is pardoned.
Behold, new things I now declare.
declaratieven.autoriteit: High, though largely quoted from Scripture rather than the preacher's own performative voice.

indicatoren: Analysis of Babylonian gods vs. Yahweh.
constatief_surplus_analyse.effect_op_hoorder: The hearer becomes a spectator of biblical history rather than a participant in a divine encounter.

performatief_deficit_analyse.effect_op_hoorder: Delayed encounter; the 'event' only happens in the final paragraphs.

toezegging_check.kwaliteit_toezeggen: The 'blanket' metaphor is a powerful commissive act.
voorbeelden: He puts redemption into our blanket.

tweede_persoon.gebruik: Direct address in the application phase ('You and I are deep in sin').
tweede_persoon.performatieve_context: Used to bridge the gap between the text and the hearer's life.

derde_persoon.gebruik: Dominant mode for exegesis and storytelling.
derde_persoon.distantie_effect: Creates a 'lecture' feel for the first 60% of the text.

actueel_present.gebruik: The 'irruption of grace' in the now.

sacramenteel_patroon.beschrijving: Assertive (Sin/Fear) -> Commissive (Redemption in blanket) -> Directive (Count yourself blessed).
voorbeelden: You and I are deep in sin... yet... he puts redemption into our blanket.
sacramenteel_patroon.kwaliteit: The transition is effective but late.

voorbeelden_goede_verhouding: If you come to know the fear of the Lord... the next words you hear will be Fear Not.

diagnostische_evaluatie.diagnose_toelichting: The sermon is a high-quality explanation of the Gospel that moves toward a performative 'toezegging' (promise), but spends significant time in the constative mode of biblical retelling.

sterke_punten.tekstueel_bewijs: He puts redemption into our blanket.
sterke_punten.effect: Creates a tangible sense of receiving grace.

zwakke_punten.tekstueel_bewijs: The detailed retelling of Gideon's meal preparation.

diagnostische_evaluatie.gebeuren_toelichting: The sermon becomes an event in the final third when the 'blanket' imagery and direct address take over.
diagnostische_evaluatie.sacramentele_toelichting: The preacher acts as a witness to the promise, though rarely uses the first-person declarative ('I declare to you').

openbaringsleer.god_als_spreker: Yes, God is the one who says 'Fear Not'.
openbaringsleer.prediker_als_mandataris: Moderate; the preacher quotes God's speech rather than speaking as God's mouth.
tekstueel_bewijs: The word of the Lord comes: Do not be afraid.

pneumatologie.perlocutie_theologie: Implicit; the 'irruption of grace' suggests the Spirit's work.
tekstueel_bewijs: through the same Jesus Christ our Lord... and the Holy Spirit.

sacramentstheologie.preek_als_genademiddel: Yes, specifically in the 'Baptism of the Lord' section.
tekstueel_bewijs: there may suddenly come an irruption of grace.

aanbevelingen.werkwoord_audit_samenvatting: Too many past-tense narrative verbs; needs more present-tense performatives.

specifieke_suggesties.huidige_formulering: Gideon perceived that he was the angel of the Lord.
specifieke_suggesties.voorgestelde_revisie: Like Gideon, you are standing before the Living God right now.
specifieke_suggesties.verschil: Shifts from historical report to immediate encounter.

toezegging_versterking.probleem: The promise is framed as a possibility ('there may come').
voorbeeldzinnen: In the name of Jesus, I tell you: do not be afraid.

adressering_verbetering.suggestie: Interweave the 'you' earlier in the narrative.
voorbeeldzinnen: You are threshing your wheat in fear, just as Gideon did.

indicatief_imperatief_herstel.probleem: The balance is actually quite good.
indicatief_imperatief_herstel.suggestie: Maintain the current foundation of grace.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A deeply theological and beautifully written sermon that successfully lands in a performative space, though the journey there is somewhat long.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_schulz_von_thun: SvT would focus on the preacher's 'self-revelation' about the NYT article; SAT focuses on the 'Declarative' power of the Word to change the hearer's status.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retoriek: Rhetoric would praise the 'blanket' metaphor for its pathos; SAT praises it as a Commissive act that binds God to the hearer.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_SAT: SAT reveals that the sermon's power isn't in the description of the Jordan's mud, but in the 'Toezegging' that Christ is in the hearer's mud.

kernzinnen_analyse.zin: He puts redemption into our blanket.

appendices.notities: The transition from the first sermon (Epiphany) to the second (Baptism) maintains a consistent illocutionary trajectory.
